definitions.definition: to teach somebody over a period of time at a school, university, etc.

examples.text: She was educated in the US.
All their children have been educated privately.
He was educated at his local comprehensive school and then at Oxford.

definitions.definition: to teach somebody about something or how to do something
definitions.sensetop: educate somebodyeducate somebody on somethingeducate somebody about somethingeducate somebody to do something

examples.text: He believed the BBC's purpose was ‘to inform, educate and entertain’.
The industry wants to **educate the public**, but not cause undue concern.
Children need to be educated on the dangers of drug-taking.
an effort to educate consumers about the importance of long-term saving from an early age
The campaign is intended to educate people to respect the environment.
We must educate people into recycling more of their rubbish.
We recognize the need to educate doctors on how to deal with these patients.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin educat- ‘led out’, from the verb educare, related to educere ‘lead out’, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out’ + ducere ‘to lead’.
